questions.question_text: Which two statements describe how the RPF check is used? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AC
The two statements that describe how the RPF check is used are A and C.

RPF stands for Reverse Path Forwarding. It is a security mechanism that protects FortiGate and the network from IP spoofing attacks.
The RPF check is run on the first sent packet of any new session. This is because the first packet is the only packet that contains the source IP address of the sender.

Selected Answer: AC
Found this also which explains C litteraly. 
https://community.fortinet.com/t5/FortiGate/Technical-Tip-Reverse-path-forwarding-check-not-working-for/ta-p/230015
Correct answer are A & D, because as indicated by its name "reverse patch check" is done on the first reply packet of any new session.

Selected Answer: AC
A. The RPF check is a mechanism that protects FortiGate and the network from IP spoofing attacks.
C. The RPF check is run on the first sent packet of any new session. 

FortiGate Infrastructure 7.2 Study Guide (p.41):
"The RPF check is a mechanism that protects FortiGate and your network from IP spoofing attacks by checking for a return path to the source in the routing table."
"FortiGate performs an RPF check only on the first packet of a new session. That is, after the first packet passes the RPF check and FortiGate accepts the session, FortiGate doesn’t perform any additional RPF checks on that session."

Reference and download study guide:
https://ebin.pub/fortinet-fortigate-infrastructure-study-guide-for-fortios-72.html

Selected Answer: AC
ref infrastructure page 41, first and second paragraph

Selected Answer: AC
The answer are A and C

choices.B: The RPF check is run on the first sent and reply packet of any new session.
choices.D: The RPF check is run on the first reply packet of any new session.
choices.A: The RPF check is a mechanism that protects FortiGate and the network from IP spoofing attacks.
choices.C: The RPF check is run on the first sent packet of any new session.

questions.question_text:
Refer to the exhibit.

A network administrator is troubleshooting an IPsec tunnel between two FortiGate devices. The administrator has determined that phase 1 failed to come up. The administrator has also re-entered the pre-shared key on both FortiGate devices to make sure they match.

//IMG//


Based on the phase 1 configuration and the diagram shown in the exhibit, which two configuration changes can the administrator make to bring phase 1 up? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
B. On HQ-FortiGate, set IKE mode to Main (ID protection).
D. On Remote-FortiGate, set port2 as Interface.

comments.content: Settings on both ends must agree; otherwise, phase 1 negotiation fails and both IPsec peers are not able to establish a secure channel.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BD
FortiGate Infrastructure 7.2 study guide page 250 last paragraph.

Selected Answer: BD
B. On HQ-FortiGate, set IKE mode to Main (ID protection). 
D. On Remote-FortiGate, set port2 as Interface. 

"In IKEv1, there are two possible modes in which the IKE SA negotiation can take place: main, and aggressive mode. Settings on both ends must agree; otherwise, phase 1 negotiation fails and both IPsec peers are not able to establish a secure channel."

Reference and download study guide:
https://ebin.pub/fortinet-fortigate-infrastructure-study-guide-for-fortios-72.html

comments.content: It is page 250 for Infrastructure study guide 7.2

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BD
FortiGate Security 7.2 study guide page 250
In IKEv1, there are two possible modes in which the IKE SA negotiation can take place: mail and aggressive mode. The settings on both ends must agree; otherwise, phase 1 negotiation fails and both IPsec peers are not able to establish a secure channel. 
Note: on the network diagram, port 2 is used on the remote Fortigate so the answer is B & D

Selected Answer: BD
The answer are B and D

choices.D: On Remote-FortiGate, set port2 as Interface.
choices.B: On HQ-FortiGate, set IKE mode to Main (ID protection).
choices.A: On both FortiGate devices, set Dead Peer Detection to On Demand.

discussion.content: D as for redundant interfaces only one stays Up therefore they do not provide extra bandwidth. B & C are out of scop

Selected Answer: D
D. ref nse4-inf-v7.2-sg pg 252

Selected Answer: D
it's D
Answer is D and it would be regardless if Fortinet or not

Selected Answer: D
D. Aggregate interface

Download study guide:
https://ebin.pub/fortinet-fortigate-security-study-guide-for-fortios-72.html
https://ebin.pub/fortinet-fortigate-infrastructure-study-guide-for-fortios-72.html

Es la D la respuesta. FortiOS 7.2 Administration Guide pag 190.
Link aggregation (IEEE 802.3ad) enables you to bind two or more physical interfaces together to form an aggregated
(combined) link. This new link has the bandwidth of all the links combined. If a link in the group fails, traffic is transferred
automatically to the remaining interfaces. The only noticeable effect is reduced bandwidth.
This feature is similar to redundant interfaces. The major difference is a redundant interface group only uses one link at a
time, where an aggregate link group uses the total bandwidth of the functioning links in the group, up to eight (or more).

The answer is D

https://docs.fortinet.com/document/fortigate/6.2.0/cookbook/567758/aggregation-and-redundancy

Selected Answer: D
The answer is D.

questions.question_text:
An administrator needs to increase network bandwidth and provide redundancy.

Which interface type must the administrator select to bind multiple FortiGate interfaces?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Correct Answer is D
D. Universally Unique Identifier

Selected Answer: D
D. Universally Unique Identifier

FortiGate Security 7.2 Study Guide (p.67):
"When creating firewall objects or policies, a universally unique identifier (UUID) attribute is added so that logs can record these UUIDs and improve functionality when integrating with FortiManager or FortiAnalyzer."

Reference and download study guide:
https://ebin.pub/fortinet-fortigate-security-study-guide-for-fortios-72.html
D correct, Fortigate Security Study Guide page 67

questions.question_text:
FortiGate is integrated with FortiAnalyzer and FortiManager.

When a firewall policy is created, which attribute is added to the policy to improve functionality and to support recording logs to FortiAnalyzer or FortiManager?

discussion.content:
Answer B should be diagnose firewall proute list (p is missing...) 
Infrastructure Guide p.59

Selected Answer: B
B. diagnose firewall proute list

FortiGate Infrastructure 7.2 Study Guide (p.16 and p.59):
"Even though they are configured as static routes, ISDB routes are actually policy routes and take precedence over any other routes in the routing table. As such, ISDB routes are added to the policy routing table."
"FortiOS maintains a policy route table that you can view by running the diagnose firewall proute list command."

Reference and download study guide:
https://ebin.pub/fortinet-fortigate-infrastructure-study-guide-for-fortios-72.html
Answer D This command will display the entire routing table, including all static and dynamic data.

comments.content: Have to revert, oversaw it is a policy route, should be B

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Tested in Lab - it´s D!

Selected Answer: B
There is a typo in there.
ISDB route --> under proutes

Selected Answer: A
To view active and standby routes

comments.content:
Answer B.
ISDB static route will not create entry directly in routing-table. Reference: https://community.fortinet.com/t5/FortiGate/Technical-Tip-Creating-a-static-route-for-Predefined-Internet/ta-p/198756 and here https://community.fortinet.com/t5/FortiGate/Technical-Tip-Verify-the-matching-policy-route/ta-p/190640

discussion.content:
Answer B
Fortigate Infrastructure Guide p.59
to me A. Thisi is a Static Route and not a Policy route. Moreover we does not know if it is active or not.

Selected Answer: B
The answer is B
